properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locally heavy rain possible today and tonight. The remnants of Tropical storm Fay will move northward across Southern Quebec today. Locally heavy rainfall will be possible, particularly during the afternoon and evening. While it is difficult at this time, to specify exact rainfall amounts, locally heavy amounts in the 50 to 70 mm range will be possible by Sunday morning. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts for further details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-12T00:42:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-11T08:43:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1026823773.2020
Area: Gatineau, Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Morrisburg - Long Sault, Prescott and Russell, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The extreme heat wave will persist until tomorrow. A warm and humid air mass continues to affect Southern Quebec. The temperatures are not expected to fall below 20 degrees Celsius tonight. Temperatures will be cooler on Saturday, however the combined temperature and humidity values will still produce humidex values between 35 and 37. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-11T15:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-11T02:05:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0603576811.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is possible today. Hazard: Heavy rain producing local rainfall rates of 25 to 50 mm per hour. Total rainfall amounts will vary significantly, however local amounts of 50 to 100 mm are possible. Localized flooding is possible. Timing: Now through this afternoon. A rainfall warning may be required for some areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-11T21:59:43-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain throughout the weekend The remnants of tropical storm Fay will affect the province of Quebec today and Sunday. Rain associated with this system could produce rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres over parts of Southern and Central Quebec. Some of these areas could however receive a total of more than 50 millimetres locally with the additional rainfall amounts produced by thunderstorms that could accompany this system this afternoon and evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-12T00:31:41-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. Hazard: Torrential rain producing local rainfall in excess of 50 milimetres per hour. Timing: Now continuing through early this afternoon. Total rainfall amounts will vary significantly, however local amounts of 50 to 100 mm are possible. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-11T19:59:00-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very warm weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing until Sunday. Maximum temperature today: near 30 degrees Celsius. Minimum temperature tonight: near 22 Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River. Remarks: Very warm temperatures will continue today and tonight as the warm air mass persists over the region. Cooler temperatures are forecast beginning Sunday night. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-07-12T05:45:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-11T13:46:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3150761858.2020
Area: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. The remnants of tropical storm Fay will affect the province of Quebec during the weekend. Rain associated with this low pressure system will give significant amounts exceeding 50 millimeters over Western and Northern Quebec today and Sunday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
